title: Dirk Geijskes
text:
Dirk Cornelis Geijskes (16 May 1907 – 27 September 1985) was a Dutch biologist, <a href="ethnologist">ethnologist</a> and curator. He was the first director of the <a href="Surinaams%20Museum">Surinaams Museum</a>. As a biologist, he specialised in <a href="dragonflies">dragonflies</a>. He would lead many expeditions into the <a href="Sipaliwini%20District">interior</a> of Suriname. In 1967, he became curator at the <a href="Rijksmuseum%20van%20Natuurlijke%20Historie">Rijksmuseum van Natuurlijke Historie</a> where he started the dragonfly collection. Geijskes is the author of 123 publications, and 25 <a href="species">species</a> have been named after him.
Biography.
Geijskes was born on 16 May 1907 in <a href="Kats%2C%20Noord-Beveland">Kats</a>, Netherlands. In 1927, he went to <a href="Leiden%20University">Leiden University</a> to study biology. In 1929, he travelled to <a href="Trinidad">Trinidad</a> to study dragonflies which would become his speciality. Next, he went to the <a href="University%20of%20Basel">University of Basel</a>, and in 1935 obtained his doctorate <a href="magna%20cum%20laude">magna cum laude</a> for a thesis on the fauna and ecology of the Swiss <a href="Jura%20Mountains">Jura</a>. In 1936, he first described "<a href="Brevipalpus%20phoenicis">Brevipalpus phoenicis</a>" which was later discovered to be the main factor for <a href="Citrus%20leprosis%20disease">Citrus leprosis disease</a>.
In 1938, Geijskes started to work as an <a href="entomologist">entomologist</a> for the "Landbouwproefstation" (Experimental agricultural station) in Suriname. During his stay in Suriname, Geijskes would lead many expeditions into the interior. In 1939, he went to the <a href="Litani%20%28Maroni%20tributary%29">Litany River</a> to study the poisoned arrows of the <a href="Wayana">Wayana</a> people. In 1941, he participated in the <a href="Sipaliwini%20Savanna">Paroe Savanna</a> expedition to the <a href="Tiriy%C3%B3%20people">Tiriyó people</a>. In 1943, he embarked on the <a href="Coppename%20River">Coppename River</a> expedition during which the <a href="Tafelberg%2C%20Suriname">Tafelberg</a> was climbed for the first time. In 1948 and 1949, he lead an expedition from the coastal area across the <a href="Nassau%20Mountains">Nassau Mountains</a>. The expedition collected about 10,000 specimens including 1,500 butterflies.
In 1954, Geijskes would become government biologist and the first director of the <a href="Surinaams%20Museum">Surinaams Museum</a>. In 1958, he lead an expedition to the Tafelberg with <a href="Rudi%20Kappel">Rudi Kappel</a> to examine the savannah around the mountain, and investigate whether an <a href="Rudi%20Kappel%20Airstrip">airstrip</a> could be built there. The successful construction of an airstrip led to <a href="Operation%20Grasshopper">Operation Grasshopper</a> in 1959 which mapped the natural resources in the interior.
On 2 May 1965, Geijskes returned for the Netherlands, and in 1967 started to work as curator at the <a href="Rijksmuseum%20van%20Natuurlijke%20Historie">Rijksmuseum van Natuurlijke Historie</a> (nowadays <a href="Naturalis%20Biodiversity%20Center">Naturalis</a>). where he started the dragonfly collection. In 2015, the collection contained 20,000 species. In the Netherlands, he also would become a member of the <a href="Royal%20Netherlands%20Academy%20of%20Arts%20and%20Sciences">Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences</a>, and editor of the "<a href="New%20West%20Indian%20Guide">New West Indian Guide</a>".
Geijskes died on 27 September 1985 in <a href="Leiden">Leiden</a>, at the age of 78.
Legacy and honours.
Upon return to the Netherlands, Geijskes became officer in the <a href="Order%20of%20Orange%20Nassau">Order of Orange Nassau</a>. He was awarded a bronze medal by the <a href="Royal%20Dutch%20Geographical%20Society">Royal Dutch Geographical Society</a>.
Geijskes is the author of 123 publications, and 25 <a href="species">species</a> have been named after him. In 1970, the <a href="List%20of%20dragonflies">dragonfly genus</a> "<a href="Lauromacromia">Lauromacromia</a>" was created by Geijskes. In 2011, it held six species.
